Introduction to Databases.title: Introduction to Databases
Introduction to Databases.description: This chapter explains what databases are, why modern systems require them, and how DBMS improves data storage, retrieval, and management.

details: A database is an organized collection of data stored electronically.
Databases help store information in a structured and efficient manner.
Used in banking, e-commerce, inventory systems, social media, and enterprise software.
To store large amounts of data efficiently.
To avoid redundancy and maintain data consistency.
To provide secure access to data with control mechanisms.
To support multi-user environments with concurrency control.
DBMS stands for Database Management System.
It provides tools to store, retrieve, update, and manage data.
Examples: MySQL, Oracle, MongoDB, PostgreSQL.
Reduces data redundancy.
Improves data consistency and integrity.
Provides backup, security, and recovery mechanisms.
Supports concurrent data access.

sections.summary: Databases are essential for modern applications, and DBMS provides the tools needed to manage data effectively.

Data Models.title: Data Models
Data Models.description: This chapter covers different ways of organizing and structuring data inside a database system.

details: A data model defines how data is logically structured.
It also defines relationships, rules, and constraints.
Represents data in a tree-like structure.
Each parent can have multiple children, but child has one parent.
Used in early mainframe systems.
Based on graph structure with multiple parent-child relationships.
More flexible than hierarchical model.
Supports many-to-many relationships.
Data is stored in tables (rows and columns).
Most popular model used in SQL databases.
Uses keys to maintain relational integrity.
Data stored as objects similar to OOP concepts.
Supports inheritance, encapsulation, and polymorphism.

sections.summary: Data models define how information is organized and accessed within a DBMS.

ER Model.title: ER Model
ER Model.description: This chapter explains entity-relationship modeling used for designing logical database structures.

details: An entity represents a real-world object.
Examples: Student, Course, Employee.
Entities become tables in relational databases.
Attributes are properties of entities.
Example: Student has name, roll number, email.
Types: simple, composite, derived, multivalued.
Primary Key uniquely identifies an entity instance.
Candidate Keys are potential primary keys.
Foreign Key establishes relationships between entities.
Associations between entities.
Types: One-to-One, One-to-Many, Many-to-Many.
Represented using diamonds in ER diagrams.

sections.summary: ER modeling visually represents entities, their attributes, and relationships for database design.

Relational Model.title: Relational Model
Relational Model.description: This chapter explains how data is stored as tables, relationships via keys, and constraints.

details: Tables consist of rows (tuples) and columns (attributes).
Each row represents a record; each column represents a field.
Uniquely identifies each row in the table.
Cannot contain NULL values.
Used to link two related tables.
Maintains referential integrity.
Entity Integrity: Primary key cannot be null.
Referential Integrity: Foreign key must match a primary key.
Domain Constraint: Values must follow defined data type.

sections.summary: The relational model provides a structured and consistent framework for storing data using tables and constraints.

SQL Basics.title: SQL Basics
SQL Basics.description: This chapter covers core SQL operations including data retrieval, insertion, updating, and deletion.

details: Used to retrieve data from one or more tables.
Example: SELECT * FROM Students;
Adds new records into a table.
Example: INSERT INTO Students VALUES (...);
Modifies existing records.
Example: UPDATE Students SET name='John' WHERE id=1;
Deletes specific records.
Example: DELETE FROM Students WHERE id=1;
WHERE clause filters data.
ORDER BY sorts results.
LIMIT restricts number of results.

sections.summary: SQL provides powerful commands for querying and modifying relational data.

Joins & Subqueries.title: Joins & Subqueries
Joins & Subqueries.description: This chapter teaches how to combine data from multiple tables and use nested queries.

details: Returns rows with matching values in both tables.
Most commonly used join type.
Returns all rows from the left table and matching rows from the right.
Returns all rows from the right table and matching rows from the left.
Returns all rows when there is a match in either table.
A query inside another SQL query.
Used in WHERE, SELECT, and FROM clauses.
Example: SELECT name FROM Students WHERE id IN (SELECT student_id FROM Marks WHERE score > 80);

sections.summary: Joins and subqueries enable advanced data retrieval across multiple tables.

Normalization.title: Normalization
Normalization.description: This chapter explains how to minimize redundancy and anomalies by organizing data efficiently.

details: No repeating groups.
Each field must have atomic (indivisible) values.
Table must be in 1NF.
No partial dependency allowed.
Must be in 2NF.
No transitive dependencies.
Stronger form of 3NF.
Every determinant must be a candidate key.

sections.summary: Normalization reduces redundancy and improves data integrity in relational databases.

Transactions.title: Transactions
Transactions.description: This chapter covers ACID properties, concurrency control, and transaction management.

details: A sequence of operations performed as a single unit.
Either all operations succeed or none do.
Atomicity — all or nothing.
Consistency — database stays valid.
Isolation — multiple transactions execute independently.
Durability — changes persist after commit.
Ensures correct results when multiple users access the database.
Techniques: locking, timestamp ordering, optimistic control.
Read Uncommitted
Read Committed
Repeatable Read
Serializable

sections.summary: Transactions ensure reliability, accuracy, and safety of data editing operations.

Indexing & Query Optimization.title: Indexing & Query Optimization
Indexing & Query Optimization.description: This chapter explains how indexing speeds up queries and how DBMS optimizes SQL execution.

details: Index is a data structure that speeds up search operations.
Works like an index in a book.
Primary Index
Secondary Index
Composite Index
Unique Index
Most common indexing method.
Enables fast searching, insertion, and deletion.
Provides O(1) average lookup time.
Best for equality comparisons.
DBMS analyzes queries using the query optimizer.
Avoid SELECT *.
Use indexes wisely.
Normalize data for faster joins.

sections.summary: Indexing significantly improves performance and helps the database execute queries efficiently.

NoSQL Databases.title: NoSQL Databases
NoSQL Databases.description: This chapter covers document, key-value, graph, and column-based databases designed for large-scale applications.

details: NoSQL stands for Not Only SQL.
Designed for horizontal scaling and flexible data.
Ideal for real-time, large-scale systems.
Examples: MongoDB, CouchDB.
Store data as JSON-like documents.
Support flexible schemas.
Examples: Redis, DynamoDB.
Fastest among NoSQL types.
Used for caching and session storage.
Examples: Cassandra, HBase.
Store data column-wise for analytics workloads.
Examples: Neo4j, ArangoDB.
Used for social networks, recommendation engines.
Represent relationships with nodes & edges.

sections.summary: NoSQL databases offer speed, flexibility, and scalability, making them ideal for modern large-scale applications.
